metadata.sermon_start_end: Something has been happening in the Church that seems different to me, both in quantity and in quality; it is happening more often and it has a sharper edge. A number of scholars with attractive personalities and considerable media skills have been steadily building a case against the Church’s [...] With all my heart I pray that you today will find the Spirit moving in your spirit, saying 'I believe in God the Father almighty, maker of heaven and earth, and in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord.' AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific pericope. It jumps between Romans 1, Mark 8, 1 Corinthians 12, and Romans 8. Consequently, it treats 'the gospel' and 'shame' as biblical ideas or keywords rather than letting a single text dictate the specific logic. It does not identify what can be found 'nowhere else' in a specific text.
quotes: St. Paul had something to say about this sort of thing in his second letter to the Corinthians...
The words of Jesus in today’s gospel, therefore, seem especially pertinent...
Let us look back at the lesson from the Epistle to the Romans.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either Mark 8 or Romans 1. Avoid using multiple texts as a thematic buffet; focus on the unique linguistic and theological structure of one passage.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is an awareness of the original context (e.g., the scandal of the cross for Corinthians/Galatians), but it is used more to combat modern liberal scholarship than to provide deep exposition of the text's own world. The preacher relies on general theological knowledge rather than specific exegetical discovery of the Greek text's nuances.
quotes: The Corinthians thought the Cross was unspiritual. They were right about that.
As for the Galatians, they wanted to drift back into forms of religious legalism...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond using the text as a weapon against the 'Jesus Seminar' and delve into the specific historical-grammatical context of the chosen pericope.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part. The preacher identifies a specific zeitgeist (the reduction of Jesus to a 'literary presence') and uses a concrete, harrowing example of a family dealing with potential suicide to ground the theology.
quotes: I know a couple whose son has for many years been a very high risk for suicide.
The mother and father know that their son... may at any time decide to end his life.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the specific text rather than from a general defense of orthodoxy.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Exposition and application are somewhat mixed, especially in the critique of modern culture. However, the sermon feels more like a lecture or an essay on 'The Identity of Jesus' than a movement where the hearer is 'expounded' by the text.
quotes: Now the iconoclasts will say that Jesus never said those words at all.
It is not at all clear on Sunday morning in the mainline churches of our land that Christ died for the ungodly.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Reduce the academic polemic against scholars and increase the direct address where the text's specific words interrogate the hearer.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' is well-defined as being 'ungodly' and the 'shame' of the cross. Redemption is clearly placed outside the self in Christ. Gratitude is less explicit but implied in the final call to confession.
quotes: He died an ungodly death for ungodly people. That was the scandal of the Cross.
If Paul is not telling the truth, then there is something that can separate us from the love of God and that is ourselves.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Make the 'gratitude' (the life lived in response to this non-shame) more concrete in the realm of 'good works' or 'church life'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon takes the 'two ways' seriously, specifically the danger of being 'lost in time' by losing the actual presence of Christ and being 'robbed' of God's arm.
quotes: Being ashamed of Jesus means being robbed of the everlasting arm of God in your darkest hour.
of him will the Son of man also be ashamed, when he comes in the glory of his Father...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Connect the 'temporal loss' (losing hope in depression) more clearly with the 'eternal loss' mentioned in the Markan text.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is strongly Christocentric. Christ is the telos, and the preacher insists on the 'two natures' (Jesus as Lord, not just a sage) as the only basis for grace.
quotes: The passage depends for its truth on who Jesus is.
If it is not true that Jesus sits at the right hand of God... then this hope... is just wishful thinking.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that Christ as 'telos' arises from the specific text's mechanics rather than a systematic defense of the Creed.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum for 'breadth'. While it has intellectual depth, it lacks the 'breadth' of staying with one text long enough to exhaust its specific riches.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition of a single passage to reach the 20-minute mark, allowing the text more room to breathe.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a theological defense of the Creed against liberal scholarship than as an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage.' It lacks a singular textual focus, jumping between several high-profile verses to make a thematic point. While the application to the 'zeitgeist' and the specific pastoral example of suicide are strong and concrete, the sermon risks being a 'speech about the gospel' rather than a recreation of a specific Word of God.
strengths: Strong contemporary application regarding the reduction of Jesus to a literary figure.
Concrete and unsentimental pastoral illustration (the suicidal son).
Clear Christocentric focus and refusal to soften the 'misery' of being ungodly.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on one specific pericope (Thesis 1.3).
Duration is slightly under the required 20 minutes for 'depth'.
Over-reliance on polemics against the 'Jesus Seminar' at the expense of textual exposition.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong theological address, but it marginally fails Dekker's formal definition of a sermon because it treats the Bible as a collection of keywords and ideas rather than actualizing one specific passage. It is a 'bicycle wheel' that is almost mounted, but the spokes of specific textual exposition are not yet tight.
